author: sahilmir

description.text:
The best thing about development tools is they usually get better as you discover what's really useful to you.  In the last iteration of this stuff, a 'debugger' showed up, which allowed you to visualize the Bezier mesh.  That thing was a good step forward, but very rudimentary, still relying on 'granules' of a sort to do the drawing.
This thing makes the drawing process a bazillion (officially measured scale) times faster.  I finally pulled enough graphics books off the shelf to figure out my vector rotation problem.  It's much easier if you think in terms of polar coordinates. (shy grin)
At any rate, the primary changes are in the maths, bezier, and test_maths files, so those are uploaded here.  
Now the drawing of wireframes comes from placing cylinders in the positions of lines.  The benefit here is that you can dial in both the radius, and the number of faces, to reduce the amount of drawing time. A bonus benefit is that if you make the lines thick enough, and use enough of them, you might actually be able to print a surface directly from the wireframe.
On the other hand, what this also does is make things fast enough that you can actually rapidly visualize how your bezier is turning out.  You can see both the control points, and the wireframe of the map in short order, and easily rotate and move it around.  
I tell you, this is pretty exciting even for me.
With figuring out the math for the cylinder placement, I have a new lease on life, and have figured out the placement for the quad patches as well.  So, I'd say one more experimental session away from actually producing the surfaces.
Final note.  If you want to play around with the line drawing, it's in the test_bezier.scad file.  It's the 'PlaceLine()' module.  There is also a nifty little thing called a segment parser.  It takes the endpoints for a line, and returns an 'array' which is essentially a data structure, containing, origin, rotations, length.  That's all you need for the line placer to do its thing.
phew...

1) Download OpenScad
2) Open up the test_bezier.scad file
3) Press 'F5'
4) Enjoy the pretty pictures
5) Modify the mesh, create your own
6) Rinse, Repeat
7) Rejoice!

UPDATE 08/26/2015 - I made this file "public" on Onshape. So if you want to edit it or add new stuff to it you can. Just go to https://cad.onshape.com/signin and make a free account. Then search "Pokeball by SpragClutch" in the public area. UPDATED TO VERSION 2 ON 06/13/2015 This is a workable Pokeball that opens and closes. It is 3" in diameter. (7.62 cm) Made it for my nephew. Enjoy! This is version 2 ("V2" in file name). I have printed and made version 2. It is good to go. Version 1 is no longer available. But if you happen to have Version 1 ("V1" in file name), these are known issues,
  • 1.75 filament fits snug/tight in hinge. On the plus side, once its in it makes a nice solid hinge. I increased the size of the hinge hole in version 2.
  • "Outer shells" needs to be manually aligned. And although super glue will work to glue it to the "main frame", a thicker glue is preferred. I add alignment slots to the "Outer shell" and the "main frame" in version 2.
    • If you run into any other problems or want something else included, please let me know in the comments. The Squirtle in the picture is done by FLOWALISTIK, and can be found here, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:319413 Thanks for looking, Made using https://www.onshape.com/

Feel Free to try and build it your way or follow the below instructions. Look at all the pictures. They will help you make this pokeball. Printing
Print the following @ 200 microns and at 15% infill unless otherwise noted.

  • 2 "Main Frames" in Black, Print with convex side down.(Like a bowl) Use Supports. The "Outer Shells" will cover the outside of the "main frame", so don't worry about how it looks on the outside. *I recommend that you print the hinge part at 100% infill (Simplify 3D allows this). You do not need supports for inside of the hinge holes, and the alignment slots. Make sure after printing, you remove all supports, including supports inside the "main frame".

  • 1 "Outer Shell" in Red, Print with convex side up. (Like a upside down bowl) Use Supports.

  • 1 "Outer Shell" in White, Print with convex side up. (Like a upside down bowl) Use Supports.

  • 1 "Button" in White, Use supports

  • 1 "Button Holder" in White, Use Supports

  • 1 "Latch". Print with 100% infill and at 100 microns.

  • 1 "Lower Latch"
    • You will also need,

  • 1 spring @ 0.185" diameter. (A pen spring will work!) (You may have to reduce the length of the spring by cutting it)

  • About 1" of 1.75mm diameter filament or something similar
    • Assemble

  • Assemble the button as per the pictures. You will have to glue the "latch" to the "button" so it does not slide out.

  • Glue the "outer shells" to the "main frames". Make sure alignment slots are aligned.

  • Glue the assembled "button assy" to the bottom "main Frame"

  • Fit the two "main frames" together using 1.75mm filament as a hinge pin.
    • CONGRATS!!! You now have a very well built Pokeball!!!

title: Case for the Pixie 40m QRP transceiver

description.text: This is a case for a super inexpensive amateur radio 40m transceiver, the Pixie. The case is for a specific variant of the Pixie, available from quite a number of different China sources for a few dollars, such as http://www.banggood.com/DIY-Radio-40M-CW-Shortwave-Transmitter-Kit-Receiver-7_023-7_026MHz-p-973111.html Note that there are many Pixie variants, and versions other than exactly the one shown will probably not fit. For the history of the Pixie, see http://www.al7fs.us/AL7FS2.html There is more info on the Chinese Pixie version here: http://kb2hsh.blogspot.no/2014/12/the-chinese-pixie-2-qrp-transceiver.html The Pixie needs an antenna, a power source, a headphone and a telegraphy key. Ideally, the Pixie is best served by a proper shielded metal case, of course.

comments.text:
I found out the issue. You have the V3 PCB and my new ones are the V 4.3. It has the Piezo on board and does not have the BNC bulkhead connector on the board (although I will put the BNC's in the enclosure}. The spacing for the earphone and key jacks is about the millimeter or two different. It is also necessary on the old board, to bend the Xtal to fit in the enclosure but reducing the height of the corner mounts can solve that.
I think the the key is a nice addition as well as the battery holder.

Most important, it is still printable on a Printrbot Simple.
http://mirage335.dyndns.org/wiki/Category:AirCoreToroidInductors High-performance, low-EMI, air-core, 0.5uH-32uH torodial inductor.
This is a completely customizable Arduino case made with OpenScad. You can configure the height and thickness of the walls and bottom of the case.

I uploaded three versions of the case to demonstrate what can be done with the OpenScad file. You can also make your custom version of the case by editing the global variables in the OpenScad file. UPDATE: You may want to increase the size of the arduino variables by 1mm and add 0.5mm to connectors position variables if you plan on printing with a wall thicker than 2mm. The white print displayed here has been print with the following values in the openscad:
arduino_width = 55;
arduino_length = 70;
arduino_usb_x = 10;
arduino_power_x = 4;

author: fedevalla

description.text:
Alright, one more. This time, the placement and rotation of each extrusion of the base shape (here, a square, but again, it could be any 2-D shape) is controlled by one equation per axis, plus an equation for the scaling, for a total of seven functions you can define any way you like.
This particular shape has no practical application (altho... if we could print pasta?) but does show that OpenSCAD is fully able to make flowing, quasi-organic shapes.
It reminds me of the stuff I used to do, two/three years ago, with TopMod.

I'm not even going to try rendering the STL on this one. :-) Play with the OpenSCAD script, have fun with it! GitHub repository:
github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/ScaleExtrudeHorns

comments.text: I think what this experimentation shows is that given a fairly simple tool, it is possible to do many extraordinary things, as long as you take a Calvin and Hobbs approach (think outside what box?).
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Yeah, basically if efficiency is not a concern (and for proof-of-concept and experiments, why would it be?) you can really push OpenSCAD pretty far from block-sphere-cylinder. :-)

comments.author: rasmuspede

comments.text: Yeah it's true that you can't get the cable shoe for the stepper motor through the links but what you can do is carefully remove each of the 4 wires from the connector/cable shoe and after that you can pry the wires through the chain links. The wires are held in place in the connector with small metal clips that can be pushed down from the tiny openings. As long as you don't push too hard and break something you will be able to reset the clips back into their upright positions. Once all the wires are through the chain links then just reinstall the connector to the wires by pushing them back into their tiny slots in the right order. It is fiddly work but it is easy compared to trying to cram all the wires into the Z axis chain links, I've done it today and it took me several hours.

From virtual to reality...!! Next step in the merger of 3D printing and augmented reality: the "Ultimarker". See it in action:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8lk9GhU36b4
http://sndrv.nl/ultimarker UPDATE: 3D file of the marker included so you can print and mount it directly on the right position.
Since we use special techniques [occlusion] the position is important to really simulate the augmented part 'inside' the Ultmaker. A project from rooiejoris [€perminutedesign] together with Sander Veenhof. [Do combine with the 3D printed google glass..!]

• Print the Ultimarker above.
    UDPATE: or 3D print the marker in 2 colours, tip: use the 'pause at height' plugin in cura to switcht colors on the right level.
  • Paste/Mount it on your Ultimaker [other 3D printers will follow]. In the 3D file a screw hole is marked, this corresponds the screw in the fornt of the Ultimaker
  • Download & install Junaio app.
  • Scan the channel-QR below:
  • Start 3D printing the Vase object
  • Point your phone [or other smart device] at the Ultimaker
    • Summary:
    Both 3D printing and augmented reality are seen as the two most impactful and radical innovations of our time. Thanks to these techniques, we now to live in a true DIY world. Want something? Make it! Be it not 'for real', then virtual. Although the techniques share a similar vision, they are opposites as well. Whereas augmented reality is instant and infinitely customizable, 3D printing takes time and the output is static. But what is the result when both are combined? A project from rooiejoris [Ã¢â€šÂ¬perminutedesign] together with Sander Veenhof.
    See also:
    http://sndrv.nl/ultimarker

This part slips in the clip of an IPod Nano (TM) to allow you to use it like a Watch.  You need a watch band - I found mine listed under Divers Velcro (TM) watch band.   They can go for like  $6.   This is a design I came up with in a short period of time.  The day it was released I bought one and made this. It was the first "Thing" I designed for my MakerBot.  I wear mine all the time, it has a few draw backs the largest is the dock connector is exposed when washing your hands. I take no responsibility if you wash your Nano and it stops working.  To get the Watch Face you can set it to Black on White or White on Black in the General Settings under Date & Time - set Time On Wake to - ON.  Then choose the color scheme under Clock Face.

Print 1 or more.  I like the face down side out as it is smooth.  Line the open side of the mounting plate with the hinge on the Nano.  You then have to open the clip to let the other side slide in under the clip.  I wiggle it until the clip falls into the hole for the clip.  This secures it in place - it takes some work reverse the process. All of this can be done gently without damaging the Nano.   None of this should be forced or require force.  I take no responsibility for anyone damaging there Nano.  No warranty expressed or implied.   Thread a watch band through it.  Wear & Enjoy!  Tell your friends I made this by printing it on my 3D printer.

title: PS4 dualshock remote bracket for Galaxy S5 with flipcover

description.text:
This set of files is quite like the original, except that I modified the device bracket to hold a Galaxy S5 with the flip-cover case  
Note that the phone holding section is very snug, which I like so the phone does not fall, but it does scratch my leather case a bit. If you want a loose fit, I would increase the depth and height of the top clips by 1mm or more. The bottom one are tight, but don't pull much due to the flexible nature of the leather flap.  
I put up the sketchup file up. There is a strange bug where the item that was imported from the STL (the "blank" I also published) won's stretch, I simply had to build on it. It does not affect the model, except that in sketchup you see a few extra lines.  
The holes take a 1/8th (3.18mm) bolt, but are quite tight, I recommend driving the bolt in and out 5 times in each piece before the first assembly.

title: Pixie complete with battery and morse key

description.text: This is essentially a super cheap morse ham 40 m band ham transceiver. Only needs an earplug and a suitable length of wire for antenna. Note that there are many Pixie variants. This one is for the PCB show here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:870586 and versions other than exactly the one shown will probably not fit. The morse key is built around a microswitch. The size of the microswitch is fully configurable. You may run the customizer to configure your own. I used a tiny one sourced from a Logitech mouse, but you may prefer to use one that is a bit larger with a bit more travel. After building, the morse key will probably need some cleaning up at its nose, to ensure full travel and avoid interference with the case. Having ensured good travel, lock the key in place using the lock ring. For the case parts, a brim support may be useful to prevent warping (depending on the build platform). For how to assemble the key to the upper case using the lockring, see the picture.

comments.text: Great design. I printed one out in Copper filament and am waiting for micro switches to be shipped and I'll post some pictures.

The Sheliak Spool Holder is designed to get the filament spool moved off of your 3D printer's frame, and snug alongside the base. It's designed for easy adjustment between different spool sizes. The Shlieak Spool Holder is our newest addition to the Sheliak component set for the PrismX. This spool holder is for the PrismX 3D Printer (http://prismx.terawattindustries.com) which works with thing:84678. It should also work with other frame designs with slight modification. It has three (3) feet for support and is designed to attach to the machine base, as a fourth support (it's not intended for standalone use). It uses acetal bushings, and can also be used with thrust bearings or 608RS (or 608ZZ) bearings. It's adjustable by sliding the outer arm in/out depending on the width of the filament spool. For the PrismX we we have rubber pads that attach to the bottom of the feet. Felt should work also to dampen vibration. This is designed to mount onto the left-rear corner of a PrismX. It's designed to be compatible with any open-frame machine, really. To modify it to work with MendelMax, Prusa i3, Aluminatus, Prusa, and other machines you'll need the parametrized SCAD files, which are being published. As always we'll link to our github repo when that happens. We'll need to modify the height of the feet for those designs. The mounting plate is made for 20mm aluminum t-slot extrusion, but we can modify it to attach to rounded frame rails also. UPDATE: The arms, dowels, and a few other things are revised after the initial prints, so we're re-printing. The base is rather large, over 260mm, to accomodate 2kg spools. It won't be printable for most, but we have ways to make it. The base could be made with a laser-cutter from acrylic or other materials. I modeled this in OpenSCAD for 1kg and 2kg spools, and the spacing required for 1kg spools still wouldn't work to get it under 200mm.

Printed Parts BOM:
  • 2x spool_holder.stl
  • 2x spool_holder_dowel_disc.stl.stl
  • 1x spool_holder_base.stl
  • 1x spool_holder_mnt_attach.stl
  • 3x spool_holder_feet.stl
    • Hardare BOM:
  • 2pcs. self-aligning acetal bushings w/8mm bore
  • 2pcs. 608 bearings
  • 2pcs. M8x40mm socket-cap (or hex head) screw
  • 6pcs. M8 washer
  • 7pcs. M4x25mm
  • 5pcs. M4x16 (20mm should work)
  • 5pcs. M4 hex nut
  • 2pcs. M4 wing nut (or add 2pcs. M4 hex nut)
  • M4 std. washers as needed.
  • M4 lock washers optional
    • NOTE: I'd recommend using 608bearings. We might get away with only using acetal bushings, and certainly thrust bearings are the smoothest but cost more. NOTE2: It should be straightforward to derive this for SAE. To assemble:
  • Press-fit the acetal bushing into the flat-side of the dowel disc (spool_holder_dowel_disc.stl). The fit is tight here - again you may need SCADs. A rubber mallet is an acceptable tool for this, perhaps desirable.
  • Insert an M8x40mm screw into the other side of the dowel disc.
  • Stack M8 washer, 608 bearing, and washer on M8 screw - on the flat side. This allows the dowel to spin on the arm. I've found that just using the acetal bushing appears to work but needs more testing.
  • Attach the (3) feet to the base using M4 screws.
  • Attach the mounting plate to the base using (3) M4 screws, washers, and nuts.
  • Attach the inner spool-holder arm (near the mount plate) with two M4 screws, washers, and nuts.
  • Attach the outer spool-holder arm (the adjustable one) with two M4 screws, washers, and M4 Wing Nuts. Perhaps assemble the wing nuts on the bottom to use fingers or a hex wrench on top.
  • Attach the assembled spool holder to the machine using the two (2) M4 mounting holes and t-slot nuts in the extrusion. For post-assembly, it's feasible, I'd recommend the Extrusion Nut Clamps from @iquizzle; but again we need an extra spacer on the feet.

Here is an adjustable wrench I made a while ago in blender, after seeing Enginerds Adjustable Wrench Challenge. I used tbusers files as a base, modifying it to have a square channel for easier printing. Once printed out it works well on loose things, but on tight things the plastic isn't strong enough. I have modified the Wrench_Arm part to print upside-down, removing the need to use support material, however I have left the Wrench_Arm STL file as the modified version (Wrench_Arm_No_support) requires good bridging settings (Something that I am having trouble with myself), although this is mainly cosmetic

You will need to print out the Wrench_Arm, Thread_Center_Hole and Wrench_Arm_No_Support STL files. If the Wrench_Arm_No_Support STL wont fit on your build platform, you can also download the two halfs as separate file (Wrench_Arm_1_No_Support and Wrench_Arm_1_No_Support) Depending on your printer you may need to use a drill bit to enlarge/clean out the alignment holes in order to fit a filament peg in. To assemble the wrench:

  • Glue the two clamp arm halfs together using short pieces of 3mm filament and superglue.

  • Glue the two threaded part halfs together around a piece of 3mm filament, leaving a few millimetres sticking out either side. This will act as an axle for the threaded part to rotate around

  • Test fit the clamp arm and threaded part in between the wrench arms, holding them together with tape, to make sure the clamp arm slides properly. If the two wrench arms don't fit together with no gap, sand the top of each part smooth until they do.

  • Glue the two wrench arm halfs together around the threaded part

  • Slide the clamp arm in to the wrench, turning the threaded part to draw it in

comments.text: Would adding a small fillet to the fixed jaw improve the durability somewhat, or is it a problem with the adjustable jaw and worm gear?

comments.text: The main problem seems to be that the moving jaw has a tiny bit of movement side to side/up and down, due to the tolerances in the channel.This causes a corner of the nut/bolt to dig in to the clamp arms and dent them. I intend to look at manually putting some support material in, rather than letting the slicer do it, but the long bridge makes it hard to get really close fitting parts. It may be that printing this out in ABS would help with the nut/bolt denting the arms, but unfortunately I don't have any to try it with

You should be confident to be able to print watertight objects. (wallthicknesses are tjar & tceram)
In the .scad file: choose anglemouth >= 45Â° for supportless printing.
The numbers in the .stl filename are explained in the *.scad file.
There are some notes for ceramic printing in the code too.
(I might try a shapeways print) If you know the "secret" of such jars or just want to have fun with your friends and don't care to spoil it for yourself, then just print it without precautions. If you don't know what this is all about, want to try it and want to be suprised
(1) either Download a final .stl or
choose Your settings in the "user area" but don't look below it.
Use F5 for a rough preview (do not turn the model) and hide the rendering window before hitting F6. Also don't inspect the generated .stl
(2) let it print from someone else. You MUST NOT WATCH while printing.
(it's not that much of a thing though)

title: Motor Mount for the Axon (plane designed by Ed of Experimental Airlines)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A nice little motor mount I designed to hold the motor for the Axon, a pusher-prop RC airplane designed by Ed of Experimental Airlines. You can see the Axon construction video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bta80gyHK7Q I had access to a Replicator 2, so I decided that I'd make a custom motor mount. The idea is to cut a 6" piece of 5/8" square wood (which I got from Orchard Supply) and this fits over the end. I then used mounting tape to hold the stick up against the top section of the fuselage. The size and bolt pattern are designed to hold the motor that Ed suggested: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=12919 It has two sets of bolt holes for M3.5 hardware, 6mm length should be fine. the horizontal set are set 19mm apart, the vertical are separated by 16mm. There is a hole in the base which takes a #4 wood screw to hold the mount on the stick. It's sized to provide plenty of clearance for a 6x4 prop. The variable "slop" below was needed to give a little extra clearance (half a mm) in the size of the opening for the stick when I printed this: it's a snug fit on my print with the Replicator 2. You might need to adjust and/or sand the stick down to get it to fit. I printed these with the face of both plates face down, and with supports. It's my first OpenSCAD model that I've uploaded to Thingiverse, so be kind. It carries my personal guarantee: if it breaks in half, you get to keep both halves.

title: Rigidbot X-Belt adjuster with offset for 16 Teeth pulley

description.text:
This is a copy of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:793499 by Walter Hsiao with the change that this has a offset to use with both original RB pulley an 16teeth pulley. The reason for the change is found here
http://rigidtalk.com/wiki/index.php?title=Pulley_Upgrade_-_36_to_16_teeth The differance is that I still use the original RB stepper motor mount and the beltadjuster with one small adjustment. The idler bearing is changed for 2pices of rollerbearing 5x3x10 mm. The M8 bolt is changed for a M5. The adjustment is not used. All adjustment is done in the beltholder adjustment.

I made this part in abs 225C /95C bed and with 0.1mm layerheight  
Orientation was with beltadjuster opening on top and manually support to the nutface above the fixed belt groove.  
M3 nutts are pressed in the block. The M3 holes are not drilled to 3mm. The tight fit acts as "nylon lock together with nut".

Also my first time printing ABS though so that has also been a challenge.   What infill did you use?

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A cooling fan for the new RepRapPro Mendel X carriage which holds up to four hotends.  
I found that a nozzle restricts the airflow too much and this open arrangement works better.

Print one of each part.  
Put a M3x18 or longer bolt through the two parts to create a joint.  
Use M3 bolts to attach a 40mm x 40mm x 10mm fan.  
Attach to the X carriage using two M3 bolts with washers and nuts.  
Angle the fan so it is pointing down towards the hotend and tighten the bolt at the joint.

I have made an upgrade to original
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:831914
i take NO credit for this one just needed some more features for my own model. it work for Prusa i3 Hephestos.
and i specially made it for use with Igus lm8uu blushing.

Ok i have a almost final version ready now working and running.
keep in mind this is running a bit tighter then the original carriage but nema 17 and standard step stick can work with it. i use Igus for min instead og ball lm8uu but you can use what you want same measurments please Read instructions for get it work. you need.

-9 strips /zip ties

• Print with support touching everywhere for get the cable chain link working!

  • then i find the perfect fit i want to glue my igus instead of cable ties, due they will pull a little on them!

  • the cable tie holes can be a bit to small for a cable tie, but can be drilled up with a 2,5mm drill if not fit perfect.

  • You have to turn your motor cable on ramps 180degree to change direction of the motor or do it on the coding of firmware.

description.text:
This model (printed at 25 mm height) is the approximate volume of an average adult male testicle. Testicle volume varies greatly among men, and is difficult to measure even with an orchidometer due to the scrotum (ultrasound measurements often disagree with orchidometric measurements). Testicles should be smooth with a firmness similar to a boiled egg. Men should regularly check their testicles for lumps or bumps, and see their doctor if they have concerns. NOTE: This model is just a model. The shape and size of your testicles are likely different. If your testicles are much bigger (like an orange) or much smaller (like a raisin), considering speaking to a doctor. Print Height = Volume
20 mm = 8 mL
25 mm = 16 mL

author: 6ZYX6

description.text:
I wanted to take a crack at making an articulated action figure for myself, and this is the current product.  The figure can be assembled without any glue or fasteners, and has 14 points of articulation.  The hands are roughly sized (somewhat arbitrarily) to hold takeout chopsticks.  I will be continuing to develop it to improve the poseability and style, and to add features/accessories, so if you don't like it right now, check back later.  
If you want to make your own parts, the balls are 10mm in diameter,  and the pegs are 3.8mm in diameter to fit 4mm holes.

Almost all the parts can be printed with 2 shells and 0% infill. The hips and torso should be printed with coarse infill, and the pegs should be printed with 4 shells and 0% infill to make them solid. No rafts or supports are necessary. Assembly is pretty self-explanatory. If you are having trouble getting things to fit, needle-nose pliers will help you get a grip on parts, c-clamps or a vise will help push parts into place, and needle files may be needed to open up holes. Cyanoacrylate glue can be used to hold the pegs in place, especially at the wrists, but only put it on one half of the peg or you will lose some of the articulation. Part quantities:
8x pegs
4x biceps, sockets
2x forearms, thighs, calves, foot
1x head, hips, torso, lefthand, righthand

Here's my attempt at fixing the SeeMeCNC hotend for printing in PLA. RostockHotEndFix4 and the corresponding STL are setup for 40 mm fans, while RostockHotEndFix4.2 and its corresponding STL are for 50 mm fans, each with a 25 mm active cooling fan.

This thing reverses the center platform essentially.  Disassemble the hotend bracket and remove the standoffs.  Standoffs are placed in the three barrels.  Don't be afraid to gentle hammer them in, the bracket is designed to take some abuse. The hotend now gets reassembled with the fans below the center section.  The top of the hotend should go (top to bottom) attachment nut, hotend bracket, hotend standoff piece, hotend.  Mount and wire fans accordingly.  
IMPORTANT: DO NOT FORGET TO ADJUST YOUR FIRMWARE.  My build height went to about 328 mm. (Still ridiculously tall and I can now print...)

author: Juanmatama

title: RapMan USB powered LED strip and mount

description.text: This is part of my webcam project. You can see my webcam mount for the RapMan at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8618 and my webcam software at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8684 I used 10 bright LED's (can't remember the MCD value) and a 10ohm resistor on a small strip of project board. I soldered the LED's with 3 holes open between each. I cut an unused USB cable and soldered the red(+) and black(-) wires to the board. I soldered the LED's right on the board's edge (1st and 2nd rows) and cut the board at the 4th row which gave me a width of about 11.9mm. My reference for the USB cable info was at http://josepino.com/light/usb_led_light My reference for calculating the resistor for the amount of LED's was at http://www.llamma.com/xbox360/mods/How%20to%20use%20an%20LED.htm but I did not use the calculator referenced on that page as it didn't work but found similar calculator at http://www.hebeiltd.com.cn/?p=zz.led.resistor.calculator The mount for the strip uses two M4 screws and I fitted it to the 8mm top rear cross bar of the RapMan printer. I aimed the LED's at the point where the extruder tip would contact the print bed. I then cable tied the USB cable to the printer's frame to eliminate the risk of it landing in the printer's belts. Next on the list for this project is a reflector strip (sort of) to fit over the LED's [EDIT] - 2011-05-11 - I am about to trash this LED strip due to performance issues. Either I used an incorrect sized LED (unlikely as it was calculated for 10 LEDs) or the LEDs are of inferior quality as the brightness slowly started fading over the course of a few days. I will be replacing this shortly with a whole new LED unit.

comments.text: A single resistor for a string of leds is not advisable. Typically, the most they'll have on a single resistor is 3 Leds when run off 12V.

description.text:
This Thing is an open source edition of our Maker Studio Winches Construction Set that we sell on Amazon. We give you all the files to print your own parts, and also we include PDF files of the Instruction Manual and Build Assembly Diagrams for four different machines that use these parts. We also offer 10 open ended Engineering Challenges (PDF file) to stretch your creative thinking muscles. Find all these in Thing Files. The four machines you can build from our PDF instructions:
  • A Popcorn Tow Truck
  • A Jeep
  • A Well
  • A Crane
    • After this you use your imagination to build your own engineering challenges. For inspiration, watch this Made by Bella video Our concept is to make it easy for you to create customized machines - cars, trucks, trolleys and others - that can move and/or lift things. You use our engineering parts to build a machine skeleton, then customize your machine body by using recycled boxes, bottles and other household items. Give this some thought, it's amazing what you can come up with. Check out this Princess Carriage, from Made by Bella Each of the four assembly builds in our Maker Studio Winches Set produces a different machine that serves a different purpose and demonstrates its own engineering principles. Beyond this, the 10 Engineering Challenges are designed to stretch your thinking; they are open ended and will push you to think creatively about how to achieve a solution. For the ultimate in creative solutions, check out how Bella takes care of her loose tooth! Made by Bella Toothpull Challenge

Download and 3-D print the following STL files, find these in “Thing Files”: Tow Hook (1 piece) Spool (1 piece) Long Connectors (2 pieces) Short Connectors (5 pieces) Medium Gear (1 piece) Small Gear (1 piece) Large Wheels (4 pieces) 7” Rods (4 pieces) 5.5” Rods (1 piece) 2” Rods (2 pieces) Hub Caps (26 pieces) Hole Punch (1 piece) Download the following PDF files for reference: Maker Studio Winches Set Printed Instructions including inventor story Popcorn Tow Truck build diagrams Jeep build diagrams Well build diagrams Crane build diagrams 10 Engineering Challenge Cards and 10 Tips NOTE: If all this printing is too much work, you can buy a commercial version of this [Maker Studio Winches Construction Set on Amazon.]( http://amzn.to/1ykEoNR)

title: Migbot Prusa i3 Overhead Spool holder

description.text:
Being tired of the "bystanding" spool holder of the Migbot i3 I thought I could put the three bolts holding the two top rod guides in place to good use.  
This spool holder attaches to the existing holes and allows to mount a spool with up to 24cm in diameter over the printer.   
This removes stress on the x-Axis where the print head has to "pull" the filament to the side, and instead allows the printhead to pull the filament downwards.  
Make sure your spool is spinning easily to avoid excess force on the direct drive.

Print the part with the big flat surfaces lying flat on the print-bed. Or, alternatively, stand it up on the smaller plate if you can't fit it into your build volume lying flat. To assemble, you need:
  • M8 threaded rod or similar, about 30cm long
  • 4 M8 nuts + washers
  • 6 M3 bolts to replace the 6 short bolts holding the top plate. I went with M3x30 bolts I had lying around but I had to use about 5mm worth of washers as you can see in the pics.

description.text: Bespoke tools for cleaning up 3D prints.

These parts are ABS only, and require 5" deck screws.
.
Use acetone to bond the two halves, clamp firmly, and allow plenty of time for the acetone to leach out. Then fill the hole with acetone for about two minutes and drain completely, at which point the deck screw can be easily inserted. Again, give it plenty of time for the acetone to go away (overnight is not unreasonable).
.
You can then use your favorite tools to cut the screw and configure the blade to your own satisfaction.
.
Created with TinkerCad.
.
UPDATE 11-JUN-15: If there are any gaps in the handle halves, acetone can leak into the part. Instead of filling the hole with acetone, you can soak a cotton pipe cleaner in acetone and use it to soften the interior of the channel.
.
Added file for "caddy" to hold the tools.
.
Added images to reflect these changes.
.

description.text: Tired of finding trying to find the hole that feels just right on your watchband? Hate having to tuck the loosely hung extra fabric away after fastening your watch only to have it pop out of place again? Meet CLASP, the printable watchband sized perfectly for your wrist and watch. Make fiddling with tiny holes and little sticks a thing of the past! CLASP is the no fuss, print to fit watch band that makes putting on your watch a breeze!

• Pick your wrist size in customizer
  • Pick your strap width in customizer*
  • Adjust Pin-size if neccessary
  • Print CLASP
  • Put watch pins in holes
  • Attach each piece to either side of watch
  • Secure timekeeping device on wrist
  • Enjoy frustration free time keeping
    • *The script automatically subtracts 2mm leaving room to attach the strap to the watch body. A 22mm width generates a 20mm wide CLASP -- to get this number measure the gap where the pins attach the strap to the watch Recommended Print Settings - 2 Shells, 340 microns, 0% infill

comments.text: This is great! It's holding my Casio F-91W together after the old strap broke. It works well in PLA and the 0% infill makes it a bit flexible too. It's also more comfortable than the old strap that came with the watch, and doesn't fall off during sports. It doesn't take long to print and it's way more secure than you would expect - It seems flimsy to look at because it's thin but it works really well.

comments.text: I really like this watchband.  It dries off faster than the rubbery one that came with the Pebble and it seems to wear better than the leather one that came with the Pebble Time Steel.  My only suggestion is to reduce the thickness around the pins.  My nozzle is around 0.4 mm, which leaves a gap between the outside and inside rings of the pins when printed at the default 1mm thickness.  This gap leads to bad prints for me around the pins and eventual separation of the inner barrel.  I'm reducing this to 0.8mm by changing "pin_radius+1,pin_radius+1" to "pin_radius+0.8,pin_radius+0.8".  (two occurrences in the code)

title: Vash the Stampede's Revolver from Trigun - remixed and supported

description.text:
I printed Vash's revolver http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251565, and while it was pretty good looking from a side view I thought it didn't really seem very imposing. So I modified Dan0nator's prop (and JersyBeast's remix) to make a design that is slightly closer to the anime gun. Here's a summary of the changes I made:
1) scaled the entire thing up by 10%
2) widened the barrel, frame, and pins while maintaining important dimensions like caliber - now it doesn't look like the barrel would explode when fired
3) made the upper part of the barrel taller to match the anime (upper and lower halves of the barrel are roughly the same size) and resized other parts to match
4) remade the cylinder and ejector into a six-shooter version from a five-shooter
5) combined the frame with the pin for connecting it to the handle, reoriented the frame and added supports

The parts should be ready to slice and print as they are - I got a non-manifold error with the cylinder mount pin but it still sliced for me.  The frame supports should easily snap off.  
Take care with attaching the handle to the frame, the pin's orientation on the frame makes it somewhat weak.  I softened the pin and hole with an acetone+ABS slurry (assuming you're printing in ABS)before attaching the handle.

comments.text: This is an awesome model but check your sizing on parts. Printing as is not a single piece fit together for me the way it should and I had to do heavy sanding and modification to make it work. Also for anyone looking for bullets the ones with thing 1582850 (The Colt from Supernatural) are the perfect circumference and just need lengthened to fit the cylinder.

author: monopolowa

description.text: File Handle

I have printed "file handle" in ABS with no support, 0.3mm thickness, infill of 50%,  nozzle 0.4 mm.  
Part List:  
1- M3X10 bolt and nut are used to tighten file (rasp)  
2- M4X50 or any metric bolt: After M4X50 bolt cap is cut, it is used to like rasp with rasp handle.  
3- M3X30 or any metric bolt:  After M3X30 bolt cap is cut, it is used to like rasp  with rasp handle.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:847659 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=847659

Using the following options: text = RWG19
base = 1
gutter = 0
font = Letters.dxf

Part of my Thing-Every-Day Summer Challenge. It was a long and hard process to design this, and it was my first attempt to make anything with moving parts. There are some obvious flaws-- the image above is one, In the rendering I failed to exclude the one piece that allows the whole thing to move, and I am to exhausted to fix that right now. Another is the size, I honestly am not 100% certain weather the base and pieces are proportional, although they should be close enough for this to function. This was a difficult design process, and as I have no printer as of now, I have no way of testing it. Like my designs? Check out my Shapeways Shop!
https://www.shapeways.com/shops/MiniFidgets PS. Sorry the designs look so cruddy. Go into thingview to examine them further, I assure you that the base is quite a bit more intricate than it appears to be from the default view. I need to learn to design with that in mind. :D

remixed_from.author: mkelly
remixed_from.title: RoBo3D Dual Fan Holder for Hexagon Hot Ends

title: Robo3D Dual Fan Holder for 3 cm Hexagon Fan

description.text:
Not only will this allow for dual parts fans or things like the Black Widow fan ducts on your Robo3D but it replaces the cheap noisy 2.5 cm Hexagon hot end fan with a 3 cm fan. Fan mounting holes are a little on the small side so that you can use screws that create their own threads in plastic parts. The two tabs in the front were removed since they are not used by anything in the current implementation of the Robo3D R1.  
If you want quieter operation use something like a Scythe Kaze fan or just get more airflow with a standard 3 cm case fan.  
Any standard 30 x 30 x 10 mm case fan will fit with no reduction in build platform or interference with the build plate.
Built in Fusion360 and exported to various solid formats. If you remix this item please supply the solid file also to make it easier for the next person.
